description.text: This is a bracket for mounting things with cable ties.  It's sized for an M5 flat head cap screw, but can likely fit similar sizes, or be drilled out (or modified with CAD) for something larger, like a 1/4-20.  It works very nicely with 6 mm T-slot extrusion, which usually uses M5 hardware.

Print with your printer of choice.  This is a simple enough part that layer height and fill won't matter too much.  The surface fill near the edges of the countersink is the most likely spot to give trouble, but since you're strapping something to that face anyway, it doesn't need to be pretty.  
The channels for the zip ties are arched, so it should bridge fine without support.
Something to keep hands busy to stop smoking

description.text: This 43" tall, 46" square dining table assembles with no hardware or glue. It is incredibly sturdy. The table is square because it promotes better community with no one placed at the head of the table and everyone equidistant, allowing for better conversation. The table takes 2 4"X8" sheets of 18mm plywood. Most cabinet grade plywood from Home Depot is 18mm and inexpensive. The one in my home is made from high grade birch ply. Please check out http://www.jeffreymatthias.com to see some of my other work. Someday, I will alter the design to allow for an expanding top to accommodate 8 people. I've added a photo of it in our home for an idea of how big it is.

There is a full diagram and cut instructions included.  I will work on an assembly instruction set, but it is overall fairly intuitive.
Finish however you prefer.

author: JeffreyMatthias

title: Hot Shoe Flash to Tripod Bracket

description.text:
This bracket mounts your flash unit to a standard 1/4" tripod for wireless lighting applications. This was designed to fit a Metz 50 AF-1 flash, but should also fit other units that have a standard hot shoe mount. This is useful if you have a flash unit that can be triggered as a wireless slave using your camera's built-in flash, or if you use wireless triggers and mount your flash to the receiver, and the receiver to the bracket.  
Also functions as a protective cover for your flash's electrical contacts.

The flash_mount.stl file contains the three parts of the bracket and can be printed all at once on a Cupcake build platform. Make sure to center the parts on the build platform in ReplicatorG prior to printing!  
Once printed, widen the hole in the bottom piece with a 1/4" drill bit and insert a 1/4" nut into the hexagonal hole. This will serve as the tripod connection. Lightly sand the top and bottom surfaces of each part until nice and flat. Glue the three pieces together using generous amounts of glue (I highly recommend using dissolved ABS in acetone for the strongest bond). Make sure the glue is completely dry and the bond is strong before attempting to fit your flash unit.  
Although I am pretty certain the bracket is strong enough, I would advise against mounting your flash in a horizontal position just in case the weight of the flash exceeds the strength of the bracket (it's made of plastic after all!). Now that you can mount your flash off-camera, there should be no need to mount it horizontally anyway.  
Also included are .stl files for the individual parts and the SolidWorks file for the entire bracket.

title: Russian Tower (cupola, onion dome) inspired by Saint Basil's Cathedral

description.text:
Cupola on Russian church tower designed by mathematical model on OpenSCAD. The PHP script and OpenSCAD program are included.
STL files for two colors are scaled to x30, shifted onto 3D printer bed (by blender), and simplified/fixed manifoldness (using meshlab).

I used Da Vince 2.0, 2 filament printer, with "russiantow-gx30fix" on green and "russiantow-rx30fix" on red.  Use any 3D CAD tool to mix two STL files if you'd like to use single color printer.  
If you'd like to change the design the shape of "onion," adjust parameters, run PHP and redirect output to file "calcmesh.scad," then run "russiantow.scad."  The parameters to decide tile design is described in "russiantow.scad."

description.text:
I drew this up as a quick test to see how level my CB build plate is.  
The idea is based on other designs available throughout thingiverse for other printers. This one is more sized for the CB's build area.  
Print it at 0.2mm layer height and it will be one layer thick. Adjust the build plate screws as needed while printing to get the best results (do level your build plate before printing), if the infill lines do not meet up, move the plate up, if they are thin and see-through, move it down.  
If you have seen other versions of this, you will have noticed that they are nearly all made up of just rectangular shapes and so if you are wondering why the circle in the middle - it is because fully defining lots of rectangles was boring.

comments.text: I used this to help me level my borosilicate bed this weekend.  However, when I first loaded it into CW 1.10, trying to slice it with 0.2LH resulted in nothing.  I had to scale up the Z of the model to 0.25mm before CW would slice anything.

I've ordered a Prusa Mendel kit and learning OpenSCAD is part of the adventure. I've opened this in repsnapper with no problem, but have no idea if it would print. If you print it, and it comes out nicely, PLEASE send me a picture :)

The variables at the top of the OpenSCAD file allow you to set the radius, the height and the density of the lines in the design. 
If you see a better way in OpenSCAD, please let me know - I'm shiny new!

description.text: Mi primera creación hecha con Photoshop

Warning >>>NOT all heated beds can be drilled !!!! ..please check that yours can. You can find the layout dims for the new holes in the included drawing Update Feb 20> Decided that it could be thinner ( now 10mm was 12mm) and removed some material to make it lighter and reduce printing time. LMU and belt clamp remain the same as does the layout geometry Designed to be printed on a 180 X 180 bed ( in 2 parts- It will actually fit on 160 mm X 110 mm)
and to allow full 200mm Y travel on a Prusa air 2 with LMU8 linear bearings.
Depending on your printer you may need to drill some holes in the heated bed.
Printed in PLA with 2 perimeters and at 60% fill Needs the following hardware :-
M3 X 35mm Allen head bolt - 2 pcs ( center joint)
M3 X 35mm Allen head bolt - 4 pcs ( stand offs for heated bed)
M3 X 25mm Allen head bolt - 8 pcs ( linear bearing clamps)
M3 X 25mm Allen head bolt - 4 pcs ( timing belt clamps)
M3 nyloc nut -18 pcs
M3 plain washer - 36 pcs

i used simplify3D and uploaded the .factory file for my profile for use on a flashforge creator. i set the layer height to 0.1mm, rectilinear infill at 30%, 3 perimeters, 3 solid bottom layers and 5 solid top layers. support was at 50% density. the thick top layers should allow you to carve the wood grain to a good depth without exposing the infill.

comments.text: I was curious how you achieved the grain of wood and weathered look on the model? I want to get the same effect on a project Im working on. Is there trick to doing it?
comments.author: ocarinakid

comments.text: the woodgrain i made in z-brush, then i used a scalpel to increase the sharpness of the grain after polishing. the weathered look is done by painting a base colour (say red) then using thin washes of black and brown and whiping off the excess so it only stains the depest areas, its best done in thin layers and built it up slowly. i then use a dry bush with a lighter colour than the base to add highlights in some areas. these techniques are used in warhammer figurines so look up some tutorials on that in youtube, the key is to never have a consistent solid colour, i build up my base layer with darker and lighter shades of the same colour, as paint never ages evenly.

comments.text: Have you tried bumping up the temp of the PLA? I typically like to run around 200C to 210C with my HICTOP Prusa i3 and I haven't had too many issues doing that. I did a quick search on the Makerbot Replicator (5th ed) and it appears it has some sort of smart extruder attached to it, correct? comments.author: Gam3r2Xtreme

comments.text: Jamming within the first seconds leads me to believe your extruder head might be too close to the print bed, prevent the plastic from coming out of the nozzle, which might be causing the jamming. Double check that your bed is nice and level using a sheet of paper. You should have a small "grab" feeling when sliding under the nozzle and bed, but not so tight that its hard to push/pull the paper under the nozzle. If you have any other issues, give me a PM since we are kind of going off topic.

comments.text: Your pain work is amazing! What kind of paint are you using? Is it all hand painted, airbrushing of a combination of both?
comments.author: Traction

comments.text: Thanks!, It's all hand painted, I used warhammer acrylic paint as that is what I had, for the glow fade on the eyes i mixed yellow and red on a surface and just kept remixing the colour as i got closer to the centre of the eye each time adding more yellow. i also never kept one consistent colour, but mixed it lighter or darker to give depth. finally to finish i diluted black paint and roughly brushed it in and wiped it off with cloth, to accentuate the textures and give it a more weathered look. i also added highlights with a fine bush. To protect it, I coated the whole thing with a matt acrylic archival spray. the painting process is simple, it just takes time to work on all the layers of paint. The techniques i used are the same you would use to paint warhammer figurines.

title: Fully printable PCB vise without glue or screw.

description.text: This is based on the "Fully printable PCB vise", but I don't have glue with me, so I modded it with a dovetail joint, it might not be visually appealing, but it works!

I remodel them with Solidworks. The primary changes or dovetail on Swirl and Bracket. The swirl has a much thicker neck (20mm) - because I broke my original one when it falled on the ground. I also found that the jaw was too tight for me, so I remodel it and loose it up a bit (enlarging radius and pitch angle, reducing the length) - still tight enough. Moreover, I can't print the vertical gap - the island is kept being knocked off, so I take them away. Sorry for the filename - I forgot which is left and which is right =P Update 2013-04-02 I remodeled the Screw and Thumbscrew.
Mine machine is vertically challenged, and it takes years to print the a half of vertical screws (because of cool down), not to mention how many times did I break the internal flap.
I remodel it, lay it down horizontally (150mm long), chop it up a bit. It's not a circle but We don't need full circle of screw for it to spin anyway, so it works. I drew a thin rectangle on the base so it is much easier to print, otherwise the 1st layer will be kept knocking down - perhaps my printer issue. For the thumbscrew, I broke 3 - the interconnect broke. So I changed the interconnect key to rectangle. It should still accept the original cross interconnect. It's much harder to break now.

comments.text: Sweet model, I played a lot of Halo back in the day and I used to make halo guns out of wood in middle/high school.  I'll have to print this!  Just FYI, the "clip" is actually a magazine -- a box that holds/loads bullets/cartridges into the gun.  A clip is an open ended structure used to temporarily hold cartridges for loading into the magazine.  You use stripper clips to load AR-15 magazines faster, for example.  The M1 Garand is loaded with clips into its internal and non-removable magazine.  Sorry lol but it bothers me when people run around calling mags clips when a clip is something else entirely.

Meine Outlander steht gerne mal im Freien, wodurch innerhalb der ersten 500km mein Zündschloss angerostet ist.
Sie ließ sich dadurch nicht immer starten. Also habe ich meinen Zündschlüssel ausgemessen und eine Kappe erstellt, die man ins Schloss steckt und somit Dieses vor Witterung und Nässe schützt. Ich würde ABS und Farbe gelb, orange, weiß oder grau, passend zum Quad empfehlen. Je nachdem, welches Modell du hast.

Die Spitze vorne nach dem Druck mit einem Messer etwas anfräsen und dann die Spitze an den breiten seiten mit dem Messer flach entlangfahren, damit dieRillen vom Drucken etwas abgeflacht werden, sonst kann es passieren, daß du die Kappe ned mehr aus dem Schloss bekommst. Wenn das gemacht iss, dann kannste das Ding sofort ins Schloss stecken.

author: augusthultman

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1k49VVNHvtU Full tutorial available on
https://learn.adafruit.com/diy-bluetooth-gamepad/ In this project we’re building a DIY gamepad using the Bluefruit EZ-Key module and a 3D printed case. The Bluefruit EZ-Key HID keyboard controller is a bluetooth breakout design for making DIY keyboards and game pads. It’s requires no programing and works with just about any trigger or push button. It takes up to 12 inputs and can be powered with any 3-16 VDC. The Perma-Proto comes in different sizes which is perfect for making all sorts of projects. The ½ sized Perma-Proto breadboard is like a business card and which makes it perfect for making a small game controller.

Full tutorial available on
https://learn.adafruit.com/diy-bluetooth-gamepad/ Parts
The parts are available in the Adafruit shop at Adafruit.com. Take a moment to look over each components. Adafruit Perma-Proto Half-size breadboard PCB
Bluefruit EZ-Key
Micro Lipo w/Micro USB
500mAh Lithium Polymer Battery
6mm Buttons
12mm Buttons
Slide switch Tools & Supplies
You'll need some hand tools, a soldering iron, 3D printer, wires and other maker tools and suppilies. 3D Printer
Soldering Iron
Wire cutters + strippers
30AWG Silicone Coated wire
PLA+Semiflex filament (3mm/1.75mm)
Panavise Jr. + Helping third hands
Heat Shrink Pack
Blue painters tape

description.text:
This is version 1.0 of my FPV monitor mount for the FlySky FS-TH9X or similar which have a steel handle at the back with a diameter of 5mm.
I needed it to mount this monitor on my transmitter: http://www.ebay.at/itm/301366829220?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1439.l2649 It's pretty lightweight but still solid. The only problem I have at the moment is, that the monitor does not keep its position. I need to add some circlips so the screws won't loosen. Maybe I edit the model to fix the M5 screws in place.

Print it and screw it together ;) You need:
6 x M5x15
4 x M5 nuts
2 x M5 wingnuts
1 x screw to fix your monitor on the mount (you can also get one here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647) I used a Prusa i3 Hephestos to print mine

author: HamOp

title: printable glowing in the dark space shuttle

description.text:
This afternoon I was looking for some nice space shuttle to print. I found one here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1966 , but it seemed to be a bit to smooth.
So I googled a little and found some fitting object in the 3D galery. I resized it and repraired it using netfabb and after a short time I printed one with a length of about 105 mm.
The upper wing is a bit too thin to be printable precisely, but it is a little more detailed than the mentioned space shuttle. But the real cool feature: It is glowing in the dark using phosphorescent PLA. The model you can download here is scaled up to a length of 135 mm hoping that this size is big enough to print a better wing. Greetings
BonsaiBrain More about this and where to get the glowing in the dark PLA: www.ifeelbeta.de
Print it and feel like an atronaut!

title: Cat Feeder with digital scale and wifi conection

description.text:
Based on the project of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27854
I added a digital scale and is conected to internet in order to know when the cat is feeding. You can see the graph here https://thingspeak.com/channels/18090.
I Have changed many thing. The screw has three turns, and is larger. So the food doesnt jam. The scale to feed the exactly food the cat needs, twice or three times a day.
Also has a display to show when is gonna feed and the actual food weight! Rv1: Added the bowl for a smooth feed :D Hope you enjoy! let me know your dudes!

comments.text: Instructions please; parts used, assembly, how you have incorporated the scale and wifi.  I would like to know how to make this project but have no clue where to begin without a walk-through.  Sounds great though :)  I would love to be able to feed exact portions and see that it has been done, with no error (or with error as the case may be) from my phone.  My cat is diabetic, and the more times I can feed her throughout the day (very small portions) the better managed the 'beties 'll be.  Everything on the market that is marketed for cat has much too large of portion sizes to be healthy for cats, especially diabetic ones.

comments.text: This is a great looking model. I thought I'd add some insight just to help people out a bit. In order to get the most efficient propeller, you will need to hollow the bottom side of the wing, and pull up the top side to make an air foil shape. This will dramatically increase the thrust generated due to the Bernoulli principal. Cheers!

This is one of the first things I designed to print on my (at the time) new 3D Printer, Bukito. It's a replacement part for a piece on my headphones that broke.  
I had good results with a 0.2mm layer height and automatic support from Cura. 0.4mm yielded way too much drooping, even with supports. May require a little fit & finishing on the outside with cutting pliers and/or a blade, and a drill bit to clean up the pin hub, but otherwise it works remarkably well.  
P.S. This is listed as the left-side yolk, but obviously you could mirror it in your software to get the right-side if that's what you need.

description.text:
Oops. A user pointed out that I posted the wrong Alibre file.
 Updated 28 May 2013 While battling ABS warping, I designed intake and exit ducts for the hot-end cooling fan. The intake duct will be posted separately. I was getting quite a blast impinging on the print surface from the back of the fan as well as the front. I have yet to make it back to testing ABS again. When I do, I'll give Triffid's suggestions a try. https://groups.google.com/d/msg/trinitylabs-talk/bqpClZElBpc/aW_RMmHR3usJ With the ducts installed and a bit of self-healing silicone tape, there is no significant draft from the fan. For PLA, I increased my minimum loop time until I can install a cooling fan that can be implemented in a controlled manner. Longer fan screws may be required, especially if the intake duct is used. Eugene
PLA Prints at 0.2 mm layer height using KISSlicer.

author: unolibrarycpl

description.text:
In addition to 3D printing one of my hobbies is "traditional" aka Hand Tool woodworking.  One of the tools that I use a lot is a marking gauge, and it never hurts to have extra around.  So I thought I would model it up and see how well it would work in modern materials.  The marking gauge is an ancient tool, and examples have been found back as far the 1500's  
What is it used for?  A marking gauge is typically used to scribe a line parallel to the edge of board.  It allows you to make repeated markings of the same width on any number of boards.  If you're making a table you want all the legs to be the same width, and you can measure once and mark multiple times with this tool.  I also use it for marking the border around a board for carving designs.  
This design borrows a lot from the historical examples, using a captive wedge to hold the beam in place, and a wedge to hold the pencil in place using friction.  I opted for the pencil instead of a cutting/scratch gauge using a nail or metal blade which is also common.  I might make an additional beam that allows for that later.

I printed mine in PLA on a Printrbot Metal Plus.  
Print one of each, including the two sizes of pencil wedges.  I found that the standard Yellow #2 Pencil worked well with the larger one.  
Slide the captive wedge into the slot (might need to sand it slightly) so that the angles match on the inside.  You want the captive wedge to be flat against the beam when you slide it in.  This allows you to slide the wedge back and forth to trap the beam in place, and slide back to release it for changing the setting.  
Slide the beam in so that it is 90 degrees off from the captive wedge.  If you have it in the same plane it will interfere with your marking.  
Slide the pencil, and insert the pencil wedge until it's tight.  You want the pencil to protrude a little under an inch.  
Line up your pencil point where you want it to mark on the board, and tighten the captive wedge to lock it in place.  If you need to adjust you can tap it slightly with a small hammer, or release the beam and reset.  
In practice you should be able to lock the captive wedge with your thumb.   
Might be worth roughing up surfaces with a light sandpaper to increase friction if you getting slippage.  
Happy woodworking!
This is your basic 4D simplex.

title: Makerbot Calibration for DC Motor Extruders

description.text: A spreadsheet and procedure for setting up Skeinforge paramaters for calibration of Makerbots having DC motor extruders such as the MK4 and Mk5

The detailed instructions are in the attached PDF file. In a nutshell: 1.) Measure your extruders volume flow rate output for a given PWM and temperature.
2.) Enter the values into the spreadsheet
3.) Select a layer height and single extruded filament width
4.) Enter the values for feed rate and W/T into Skeinforge
5.) Verify the single extruded filament width against a thin walled test piece.
6.) Print and enjoy your newly calibrated Makerbot

comments.text: Let me start by saying I have a basic cupcake with gen3 electronics running a MK5 extruder with a relay board. I have found strange behavior when running at PWM other than 255. I test this by using the control panel to heat up the toolhead then try extrusions at PWM values other than 255. I  have found that there are some ranges, in my case between 235 and 254, where the extruder will not respond to a stop command and I start to see large glitches in the temperature graph. Is this what you see or will your extruder simply not run?

When i first tried dave durants tool I was able to print fine at variable pwm, since then i had an issue with a printed wades style tensioner giving out and causing the dc motor to stall/strip filament. After i reverted to the stock tensioner i could no long print at anything below 255, yet at 255 it worked fine.

title: Ford Focus Dash Mount (for use with Sync console)

description.text: I designed this to hold my Note 3 (that's in an Otter Box) on my dash board, clipped on the edge over the sync display.  The base parts should work well with a lot of different items, like GPS, dash cams, etc, by trading out the cross bar and/or the phone clips.

Right now, this is printed in PLA, it's winter.  I will probably reprint in PET once the seasons start changing.  
The screw that secures the center post is designed to be an M3, with a nut embedded on the inside of the cylinder wall.  
The cross bracket is secured with #6 machine screw and nut.  
The base ring is meant to be glued to the main clip.  I used gorilla glue.  In in some cases, light, non-permanent adhesive might be used in case the clip is not fixed firm enough.

author: kczujko

title: Another Spool Holder for the Mendel90

description.text:
I had quite a lot of trouble searching for the right spool holder. I tried out some designs, but none of them really suited my needs. This holder can handle spool diameteres up to 25cm and above that you can still use the original one. Spool widths can be up to 96mm. But you can easily modify it to handle even bigger ones. Even narrow spools don't tip over, even tough I got the "Heavy duty Vibration dampers" (Thing 94733) installed. They create movement of about 5mm in the top part. The spool holder just clips on to the top edge of the dibond plate. Thing 263242 was my inspiration for that feature. Friction keeps them from moving to the side. The spool holder reduces the stress on the gantry to a minimum. The two tubes roll on ball bearings (6203 (17x40x12)).The stop plate keeps them from coming of. You can use 3,5x10mm srcews to secure it. I just glued mine in place with hotglue. You have to sand the rod quite a bit to make a good fit with the bearings. I use a slightly smaller diameter on the middle part to reduce sanding. I needed to create a new filament guide. It doesn't have a dust filter, you have to print one that clips on to the top of the extruder. I prefer to do it like that, to keep the friction close to the extruder.
I use thing 190118 for that. I hope you like my design, if you print it, fell free to post some pictures!

author: LeosLetsPrint

title: Clipped Wing Spitfire MK XVI with Bubble Canope

description.text: Clipped Wing Spitfire MK XVI with Bubble Canope. First try editing with meshmixer to make an R/C model #MadeInBelgium #iwannaseemakes

Hunt the i-net for your favourite plane in stl or obj format.
Download it.
Open and edit in meshmixer.
First cut the model in wings and front and back body,
Boolean substract a beam in the length of the plane,
Make some rods and substract them in the wings and tail.
Cut the wings off, using ctrl-z and ctrl-c, &ctrl-v,
Keep them and save them separatly.
at last, substract a rod in the nose for a motor/leads/spinneraxle.
In this THING, the aircatchers under the wings are gone. i wanted too print them separately, but i accidently deleted them.
(with the plane cut in meshmixer, you tend too lose the cutted part, thats why there is ctrl-z and ctrl-c: Cut, ctrl c the rest part, undo, paste the rest part, then use the rest part to line-up your new plane cut points)
pss. the tailwing's back rod, has been placed too high and will come thrue its wing surface. But it aint anything a real modelbuilder cant fix.
Remember.
We want pictures!
And, if you want us to throw our MIG15 on Thiniverse too,show us you like planes by clicking LIKE and/or donating something!

comments.text:
this model flies with following printer settings;
0.3nozzle
cura & slic3r
vase settings in cura for body parts,
single wall perimerter & 4% infill in slic3r for the wings.
Save as .gcode & u'll have your printable flying model,
hollow carbon rods trough, and start drilling the steering rod holes. make balsa servomounts fyormicro servo, cause printed plastic would be too heavy for this.
i made a 42cm wingspan, & a 64cm wingspan spit fly. the 42cm with Microflight.com radio gear, a LiFe 18650 accu, a 1600kv micro drone brushless 6a motor & esc, &parkzone microservo's., some straws and carbon rods. i do suggest an 3 axial gyro, cause such small models are a... ehm. difficult too fly. the 64cm flew like a dream until it met that one lonely tree on the field.
so, a 20x20x18cm printer can print a flying spit, but it rquires some years of building flying models & capacity to weight ratio accu knowledge.
a bigger printer, like a 30x30x30 cm, can print a stable flying spit.
A Mig-15 project, well , that failed. electric ducted fans are just... pathetic. its makes a pretty remote controlled car tho.

title: LongSnake
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a longer version of the Snake, even more fun and bendy than the original. It's too large to fit on a Makerbot or ToM, so you will need something like a RapMan or RepRap to print it. Or you could chop it in half and print in two parts. There are two versions. The default LongSnake is designed to have a center core section that is two filament widths thick. LongSnakeThin has a thinner, single filament thick center, so it's more flexible as a result. I recommend the thin version for PLA, at least. Both are oriented diagonally on the printbed to fit nicer. Dimensions:
LongSnake: 137.4mm x 137.4mm x 11.1mm tall (190mm long)
LongSnakeThin: 144.3mm x 144.2mm x 11.7mm tall (199.5mm long) The thin version is slightly larger because Skeinforge was giving me trouble. I have been printing with 0.3mm layers and 2.0 width/thickness, so increasing the center thickness to just slightly over 0.6mm helped a lot.

description.text: WIP...

A dumbell used for dog training with keychain hole
IPO 2

Just a simple hook. If you print it in the intended z-direction (see print bed gallery file) it is quite sturdy and there shouldn't be any delamination problems between layers. The attachment bores are for countersunk screws and arranged such that they are accessible for drilling and mounting the screws without any parts of the hook interfering. The supplied stl is for a 60mm length hook, attachment bores are for 3mm countersunk screws. The scad file is supplied and is parametric. The scad makes use of the hull construction technique I find quite useful. This hook was inspired
by Parametrized wall-hook
by q_h http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29889,
but the scad was written from scratch.

You can either print the supplied 60mm hook stl.   
Mine was printed in PLA with 25% infill and is quite sturdy. The attachment bores are for 3mm countersunk screws.  
Or adjust the supplied scad file to your specific needs (adjust the Pxx params).

remixed_from.author: MakerCultureTutorials
remixed_from.title: Quick & Dirty iPhone6 Plus Tripod Holder - no hardware needed.

title: Quick and Dirty iPhone 6 Tripod Mount

description.text:
Eactly the same as the original but not as wide to fit the normal iPhone6. Text from the original follows. Just a quick adapter to hold an iPhone6 for mounting on a tripod. It clips onto the back of the iPhone and screws to a standard 1/4"-20 screw on a tripod head (without a metal nut).
The design is not very strong or durable - as it needs to bend in order to clip onto the phone and because I wanted to avoid the need for a metal nut for the 1/4" thread.
But it prints very quickly, therefore you can replace it as often as needed.
Please be mindful of the functional limitations of this thing in order to avoid damage to your phone. Don't use it to mount your 1000$ iPhone on top of your race car, for instance...
Make sure to print in a resolution that is high enough to allow for the threads in the bottom of the thing to be represented well enough for the tripod screw to engage with. Note that Oon my Prusa I3 a layer height of .3 worked fine.

The four-point bed support was beginning irritate me. My T1 heater wires were also working towards inevitable fatigue or kapton/copper failure. So, I fixed both with one part. An M4 x 6 mm set screw is used to provide a leveling adjusment (McMaster PN 91313A139). I use a 32 mill sheet of FR4/G-10 (McMaster PN 8667K51) under my heater. This provides some thermal insulation, supports, and protects the heater and glass from the set screw stress. Something similar would also work. Look for companion bed corners too. Demonstration video: http://youtu.be/n6wtOR66uoA Eugene
ABS printed at 0.2 mm layer.

comments.text: I suggest that you use a "Chicago Screw" post instead of a set-screw - less likely to penetrate the heater: http://www.amazon.com/Aluminum-Screw-Posts-Chicago-Screws/dp/B003O5GPHU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1368136920&sr=8-1http://www.amazon.com/Aluminum...

comments.text: Interesting screw style (Binding Post or Chicago Screws). I have not used these before. The female thread could be pressed in from the bottom. A little thread sealer would provide some resistance to rotation during machine operation.

After spending a long afternoon, the three-point won't fit my batch two machine - the wires are thicker, they come off the bed in the wrong direction, and there is not enough room for the wires under the middle "corner".
And the Chicago screw raises the glass too high at its minimum height.
Sigh...
